## Conversation that answers the provided questions:
**User:**
I'm about to update Verus to a new version. What's the first step I should take?

**AI Assistant:**
When updating Verus to a new version, the first step is to stop the Verus daemon by running the command `./verus stop`. This ensures that the daemon is not running while you update the binaries. It's an important step to avoid any potential issues during the update process.

**User:**
That makes sense. What about the old versions of the binaries? Should I do something with them?

**AI Assistant:**
Yes, it's a good practice to rename the old versions of the binaries when updating Verus. This ensures that you can easily revert to the old version by renaming these files if needed. This provides a safety net in case something goes wrong during the update process.

**User:**
I store my Verus wallet.dat, Chaindata, and VRSC.conf files in a non-standard location, such as an external hard drive. What do I need to do?

**AI Assistant:**
If your Verus files are stored in a non-standard location, you may have a `datadir` specified in your VRSC.conf file. After updating Verus, navigate to the directory where your files are stored and check that the `datadir` is still correct. If it's not, edit the VRSC.conf file to append the correct `datadir` path.

**User:**
How do I start the Verus daemon again after updating to a new version?

**AI Assistant:**
To start the Verus daemon again after updating to a new version, simply run the command `./verusd`. You can add any other start options as needed, which can be found in the Verus documentation.

**User:**
How can I verify that the new version of Verus is working correctly?

**AI Assistant:**
You can verify that the new version of Verus is working correctly by running the command `./verus getwalletinfo`, which will display information about your wallet. If the command runs successfully and displays the expected information, it's a good indication that the new version is working correctly.
AI Assistant
N/A
What is the first step to take when updating Verus to a new version?

The first step to take when updating Verus to a new version is to stop the Verus daemon by running the command `./verus stop`. This ensures that the daemon is not running while you update the binaries.

7. STOP the Verus daemon
    ./verus stop
  Check whether it has stopped running with this command. (To be doubly sure you can also look in the debug file in the )
    top
  (This time `verusd` should **NOT** appear in this list.)
8. Rename the old versions of the binaries (replace the version numbers with the version being replaced)
  (This ensures you can easily revert to the old version by renaming these files.)
    mv verus verus-v0.7.3-9
    mv verusd verusd-v0.7.2-9
9. Check they have been renamed
    ls-la
10. Unpack/unzip the binaries for the latest version
    tar -xvf Verus-CLI-Linux-v0.7.3-10-arm64.tar.gz
11. Check if they have unpacked/unzipped in the directory
    ls -la
12. If the directory where your Verus wallet.dat, Chaindata & VRSC.conf files are stored is in a non standard place - eg on a mounted external hard drive - you may have a datadir specified in your VRSC.conf file.
  Navigate to that directory to check your datadir is still correct. The VRSC.conf file may have been overidden in the update. This ensures the Verus daemon knows where to find the blockchain you have currently saved on your system.
    cat VRSC.conf
  If it requires editing, use nano to edit this file
    nano VRSC.conf
  & append this to the VRSC.conf file :  
    datadir=[your custom file path for your mounted hard drive]
13. Start the Verus daemon again on the new version (add any other start options from https://wiki.verus.io/#!faq-cli/clifaq-01_verusd_options.md)
    ./verusd
14. Check the version
    ./ verus getwalletinfo
15. Once you are satisfied the new version is working, clean up the older binares (from step 8) by deleting them (or just move them to another directory using the same mv command as step 8)
    rm verus verus-v0.7.3-9
    rm verus verusd-v0.7.3-9
